versionNotes: Sprint 2 evidence design — AI-guided self-reflection to deepen evidence planning
title: Evidence Design: What Will You Demonstrate?
description:
Your Sprint 2 demo uses a 5-slide format to tell a growth story. Before collecting evidence, you need to design what that evidence will look like — and AI feedback will help you go deeper than your first instinct.

The 5 slides: (1) The quality & why it matters, (2) Your starting point, (3) What you did, (4) Evidence of growth, (5) Your trajectory / what's next.

For each question below, enter your initial response, then use the AI-generated questions to push your thinking further. Strong evidence = before/after comparisons, external feedback, specific examples with dates, measurable change. Weak evidence = "I feel like I improved," effort without results, vague claims, only self-assessment.

questions.prompt: Slide 2 — How will you capture your starting point? A before-and-after requires a clear "before." What will you document now so you have a baseline? (recording, screenshot, self-rating, writing sample, etc.)
questions.partnerInstructions: Enter your initial plan for capturing your starting point. Be as specific as you can — what format, when you'll do it, and what exactly you'll capture.
questions.placeholder: Describe your plan for documenting your baseline...
questions.aiContext: This is a Sprint 2 evidence design activity in CST349 (Professional Seminar). The student is planning how to capture their starting point (baseline) for a professional skill they're developing. They need to document a clear 'before' state so they can show growth later in a 5-slide demo. Push them on: Is the baseline measurable or just a feeling? Would a stranger be able to understand where they started? Is this something their group partners could verify? Could they be more specific about format, timing, or what exactly they'll capture?
questions.discussionPrompt: Review the AI's follow-up questions. Reflect on whether your baseline plan is specific enough that someone outside your group could understand where you started. Refine your thinking below.

questions.prompt: Slide 3 — What specific actions will you take? List 3-5 concrete things you'll do over the next 3 weeks. Be specific enough that your group partners could verify you did them.
questions.partnerInstructions: Enter your planned actions. For each one, try to include: what you'll do, how often, and what the observable output will be.
questions.aiContext: This is a Sprint 2 evidence design activity in CST349 (Professional Seminar). The student is listing specific actions they'll take to develop a professional skill over the next 3 weeks. Strong plans have: observable outputs (not just internal intentions), realistic frequency, and actions that are verifiable by group partners. Push them on: Are these actions or just intentions? How would a group partner know you did them? Are 3 weeks enough for this pace? What's the difference between effort (doing things) and evidence (proving growth)?
questions.discussionPrompt: Review the AI's questions. Consider whether your actions are truly verifiable and whether they'll produce evidence of growth — not just evidence of effort. Refine below.

questions.prompt: Slide 4 — What counts as evidence of growth? How will you prove improvement — not just effort? What would be undeniable to someone who doesn't know you?
questions.partnerInstructions: Describe what evidence of actual growth will look like. Think about what would convince a skeptic, not just you.
questions.placeholder: Describe what evidence of growth will look like...
questions.aiContext: This is a Sprint 2 evidence design activity in CST349 (Professional Seminar). The student is designing what evidence of growth will look like for their professional skill. The key distinction is between strong evidence (before/after comparisons, external feedback, specific examples with dates, measurable change) and weak evidence ('I feel like I improved,' effort without results, vague claims, only self-assessment). Push them on: Would this evidence convince someone who has never met you? Is this measuring growth or just activity? Could your group partners confirm this? What's the difference between 'I did things' and 'I got better'?
questions.discussionPrompt: The AI's questions should challenge whether your evidence plan actually measures growth vs. effort. Consider: would a stranger find this convincing? Refine below.

questions.prompt: What could go wrong with your evidence plan? What if the evidence doesn't show growth? What's your backup? Be honest about the risks.
questions.partnerInstructions: Be honest about vulnerabilities in your plan. What are the realistic scenarios where this doesn't work out?
questions.placeholder: Describe what could go wrong and your contingency plan...
questions.aiContext: This is a Sprint 2 evidence design activity in CST349 (Professional Seminar). The student is identifying risks in their evidence plan and developing contingencies. Common pitfalls: choosing evidence that's easy to fake, relying on a single data point, not accounting for external factors, setting the bar too low (guaranteed 'growth') or too high (impossible to show progress). Push them on: Are you being honest about what might fail? What if your baseline was wrong? What if you do the work but growth is hard to measure? Is your backup plan just a weaker version of the same thing, or a genuinely different approach?
questions.discussionPrompt: Review the AI's challenges to your risk assessment. Are you being genuinely honest about what could fail, or just listing safe risks? Refine below.
